SEARCH
Package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful

Class TrigTools

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.TrigTools
public final class TrigTools extends Object
Trigonometric approximations for sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), and atan2(), with variants for most that allow users to trade speed for precision or vice versa. This is primarily derived from libGDX's MathUtils class. Unlike MathUtils, it exposes much more of its internal data, trusting that users can know what they are doing. A key difference here is that all methods have variants that treat angles as radians, as degrees, and as turns. That is, while a full rotation around a circle is 2.0 * PI radians, it is 360.0 degrees, and it is 1.0 turns.
This contains four fairly-sizeable lookup tables for some methods (in total RAM usage, just over 384KB); two store 16385 results of sin() (one as float, one as double) and the other two store 16385 results of cos() (as float and as double). Yes, I know they are the same data, just offset from each other or as a different type; some of the methods here run so briefly that getting the index with offset nearly doubled the time taken by the method. Here, sin(float), cos(float), and tan(float) use the LUTs. Other methods here use techniques ranging from basic Taylor series to Pad√© approximants. The lookup-table-based sin() and cos() can be extraordinarily fast if the 64KB table can stay in a processor cache, while the "smooth" approximations may have decent quality but perform less quickly compared to an in-cache lookup table. Available now are "precise" versions of all methods here, such as sinPrecise(float). The "precise" versions all avoid a lookup table entirely and tend to be the most precise approximations here, while still outperforming Math versions of their function. In a few cases, the "precise" versions are also the fastest; this occurs most often for tan variants, or situations where a large lookup table is not possible for the processor to cache.
Relative to MathUtils in libGDX, the main new functionalities are the variants that take or return measurements in turns, the now-available SIN_TABLE, and COS_TABLE. Using the sin or cos table directly has other uses mentioned in its docs (in particular, uniform random unit vectors).
MathUtils had its sin and cos methods created by Riven on JavaGaming.org . The versions of sin and cos here, including the way the lookup table is calculated, have been updated several times by Tommy Ettinger. The asin(), acos(), and atan() methods all use Taylor series approximations from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation; though one might think such code would be obsolete over 60 years later, the approximations from that study seem to have higher accuracy and speed than most attempts in later decades, often those aimed at DSP usage. Even older is the basis for sinSmooth() and cosSmooth(); the versions here are updated to be more precise, but are closely related to a 7th-century sine approximation by Bhaskara I. The update was given in this Stack Exchange answer by WimC. From the same site, this Stack Exchange answer by Soonts provided the tan() method used here. The atan2Finite() family of methods is based on the very fast structure given by commenter "imuli" on Nic Taylor's DSP article, but uses the last atan() Taylor series approximation from the aforementioned 1955 research study. The "precise" methods are all drawn from Jolt Physics and its Vector4 implementation, which is where that library's trigonometry code ends up calling. Jolt uses SIMD optimization for its trigonometry and other math code, which unfortunately has no cross-platform counterpart in Java at the time of writing (June 2025); the "precise" methods here are mostly ports of the C++ methods with the SIMD-specific code replaced with scalar code. Jolt was written by Jorrit Rouwe and is MIT-licensed; the code based on Jolt here was in turn based partly on code for the Cephes library by Stephen L. Moshier.

    Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).

    • TABLE_MASK

      public static final int TABLE_MASK
      The bitmask that can be used to confine any int to wrap within TABLE_SIZE. Any accesses to SIN_TABLE with an index that could be out of bounds should probably be wrapped using this, as with SIN_TABLE[index & TABLE_MASK].
      See Also:

    • SIN_TABLE

      public static final float[] SIN_TABLE
      A precalculated table of 16385 floats, corresponding to the y-value of points on the unit circle, ordered by increasing angle. This should not be mutated, but it can be accessed directly for things like getting random unit vectors, or implementing the "sincos" method (which assigns sin() to one item and cos() to another).
      A quick way to get a random unit vector is to get a random number that can be no larger than the table size, as with int angle = (random.nextInt() & TrigTools.TABLE_MASK);, and look up that angle in COS_TABLE for the vector's x and SIN_TABLE for the vector's y. Elements 0 and 16384 are identical to allow wrapping.

    • COS_TABLE

      public static final float[] COS_TABLE
      A precalculated table of 16385 floats, corresponding to the x-value of points on the unit circle, ordered by increasing angle. This should not be mutated, but it can be accessed directly for things like getting random unit vectors, or implementing the "sincos" method (which assigns sin() to one item and cos() to another).
      A quick way to get a random unit vector is to get a random number that can be no larger than the table size, as with int angle = (random.nextInt() & TrigTools.TABLE_MASK);, and look up that angle in COS_TABLE for the vector's x and SIN_TABLE for the vector's y. Elements 0 and 16384 are identical to allow wrapping.

  • Method Details

    • radiansToTableIndex

      public static int radiansToTableIndex(float radians)
      Converts radians to an index that can be used in SIN_TABLE or COS_TABLE to obtain the sine or cosine of the given angle. This method can be useful if you have one angle and want to get both the sine and cosine of that angle (called the "sincos()" function elsewhere). This tries to round the given angle to the nearest table index.
      Parameters:
      radians - an angle in radians; may be positive or negative
      Returns:
      the index into SIN_TABLE of the sine of radians

    • degreesToTableIndex

      public static int degreesToTableIndex(float degrees)
      Converts degrees to an index that can be used in SIN_TABLE or COS_TABLE to obtain the sine or cosine of the given angle. This method can be useful if you have one angle and want to get both the sine and cosine of that angle (called the "sincos()" function elsewhere). This tries to round the given angle to the nearest table index.
      Parameters:
      degrees - an angle in degrees; may be positive or negative
      Returns:
      the index into SIN_TABLE of the sine of degrees

    • turnsToTableIndex

      public static int turnsToTableIndex(float turns)
      Converts turns to an index that can be used in SIN_TABLE or COS_TABLE to obtain the sine or cosine of the given angle. This method can be useful if you have one angle and want to get both the sine and cosine of that angle (called the "sincos()" function elsewhere). This tries to round the given angle to the nearest table index.
      Parameters:
      turns - an angle in turns; may be positive or negative
      Returns:
      the index into SIN_TABLE of the sine of turns

    • sin

      public static float sin(float radians)
      Gets an approximation of the sine of radians. This offers about 2x to 4x the throughput of Math.sin(double) (cast to float).
      Internally, this uses SIN_TABLE, but interpolates between two adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
      Parameters:
      radians - an angle in radians; optimally between -PI2 and PI2
      Returns:
      the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive

    • cos

      public static float cos(float radians)
      Gets an approximation of the cosine of radians. This offers about 2x to 4x the throughput of Math.cos(double) (cast to float).
      Internally, this uses COS_TABLE, but interpolates between two adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
      Parameters:
      radians - an angle in radians; optimally between -PI2 and PI2
      Returns:
      the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive

    • tan

      public static float tan(float radians)
      Gets an approximation of the tangent of radians. This offers much higher throughput than Math.tan(double) (cast to float).
      Internally, this gets one table index from the given angle (rounding down) and quickly gets another index by adding 1 (effectively rounding up). The down and up indices are looked up in SIN_TABLE and COS_TABLE, the sines are interpolated, the cosines are interpolated, and the sine is divided by the cosine.
      Parameters:
      radians - a float angle in radians, where 0 to PI2 is one rotation
      Returns:
      a float approximation of tan()

    • sinDeg

      public static float sinDeg(float degrees)
      Gets an approximation of the sine of degrees. This offers about 2x to 4x the throughput of Math.sin(double) (converted from degrees and cast to float).
      Internally, this uses SIN_TABLE, but interpolates between two adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
      Parameters:
      degrees - an angle in degrees; optimally between -360 and 360
      Returns:
      the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive

    • cosDeg

      public static float cosDeg(float degrees)
      Gets an approximation of the cosine of degrees. This offers about 2x to 4x the throughput of Math.cos(double) (converted from degrees and cast to float).
      Internally, this uses COS_TABLE, but interpolates between two adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
      Parameters:
      degrees - an angle in degrees; optimally between -360 and 360
      Returns:
      the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive

    • tanDeg

      public static float tanDeg(float degrees)
      Gets an approximation of the tangent of degrees. This offers much higher throughput than Math.tan(double) (converted from degrees and cast to float).
      Internally, this gets one table index from the given angle (rounding down) and quickly gets another index by adding 1 (effectively rounding up). The down and up indices are looked up in SIN_TABLE and COS_TABLE, the sines are interpolated, the cosines are interpolated, and the sine is divided by the cosine.
      Parameters:
      degrees - a float angle in degrees, where 0 to 360 is one rotation
      Returns:
      a float approximation of tan()

    • sinTurns

      public static float sinTurns(float turns)
      Gets an approximation of the sine of turns. This offers about 2x to 4x the throughput of Math.sin(double) (converted from turns and cast to float).
      Internally, this uses SIN_TABLE, but interpolates between two adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
      Parameters:
      turns - an angle in turns; optimally between -1 and 1
      Returns:
      the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive

    • cosTurns

      public static float cosTurns(float turns)
      Gets an approximation of the cosine of turns. This offers about 2x to 4x the throughput of Math.cos(double) (converted from turns and cast to float).
      Internally, this uses COS_TABLE, but interpolates between two adjacent entries in the table, rather than just using one entry unmodified.
      Parameters:
      turns - an angle in turns; optimally between -1 and 1
      Returns:
      the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive

    • tanTurns

      public static float tanTurns(float turns)
      Gets an approximation of the tangent of turns. This offers much higher throughput than Math.tan(double) (converted from turns and cast to float).
      Internally, this gets one table index from the given angle (rounding down) and quickly gets another index by adding 1 (effectively rounding up). The down and up indices are looked up in SIN_TABLE and COS_TABLE, the sines are interpolated, the cosines are interpolated, and the sine is divided by the cosine.
      Parameters:
      turns - a float angle in turns, where 0 to 1 is one rotation
      Returns:
      a float approximation of tan()

    • sinPrecise

      public static float sinPrecise(float radians)
      A non-tabular sine approximation in radians that is typically faster than Math.sin(double) and accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to PI2 range. While this is slower than sin(float), it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are significantly more accurate than sin().
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      radians - input in radians, typically between -PI2 and PI2 for greatest precision
      Returns:
      the sine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive

    • cosPrecise

      public static float cosPrecise(float radians)
      A non-tabular cosine approximation in radians that is typically faster than Math.cos(double) and accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to PI2 range. While this is slower than cos(float), it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are significantly more accurate than cos().
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      radians - input in radians, typically between -PI2 and PI2 for greatest precision
      Returns:
      the cosine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive

    • sinDegPrecise

      public static float sinDegPrecise(float degrees)
      A non-tabular sine approximation in degrees that is typically faster than Math.sin(double) and accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 360 range. While this is slower than sinDeg(float), it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are significantly more accurate than sinDeg().
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      degrees - input in degrees, typically between -360 and 360 for greatest precision
      Returns:
      the sine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive

    • cosDegPrecise

      public static float cosDegPrecise(float degrees)
      A non-tabular cosine approximation in degrees that is typically faster than Math.cos(double) and accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 360 range. While this is slower than cosDeg(float), it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are significantly more accurate than cosDeg().
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      degrees - input in degrees, typically between -360 and 360 for greatest precision
      Returns:
      the cosine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive

    • sinTurnsPrecise

      public static float sinTurnsPrecise(float turns)
      A non-tabular sine approximation in turns that is typically faster than Math.sin(double) and accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 1 range. While this is slower than sinTurns(float), it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are significantly more accurate than sinTurns().
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      turns - input in turns, typically between -1 and 1 for greatest precision
      Returns:
      the sine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive

    • cosTurnsPrecise

      public static float cosTurnsPrecise(float turns)
      A non-tabular cosine approximation in turns that is typically faster than Math.cos(double) and accurate to within two ULPs for inputs in the 0 to 1 range. While this is slower than cosTurns(float), it is usually a little more accurate, and its worst-case results are significantly more accurate than cosTurns().
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      turns - input in turns, typically between -1 and 1 for greatest precision
      Returns:
      the cosine of the given angle as a float, between -1 and 1 inclusive

    • tanPrecise

      public static float tanPrecise(float radians)
      Returns the tangent in radians; non-tabular and very precise, but about half as fast as tan(float). This method is only very slightly more precise than tan(); the difference is only about 2 ULPs for the worst-case absolute error in the -1 to 1 range, though the error almost certainly balloons significantly near the undefined inputs at odd multiples of HALF_PI. The main reason to use this method is that it is non-tabular. If the SIN_TABLE and COS_TABLE arrays are not in processor cache, this non-tabular method may become faster.
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      radians - a float angle in radians, where 0 to PI2 is one rotation
      Returns:
      a float approximation of tan()

    • tanDegPrecise

      public static float tanDegPrecise(float degrees)
      Returns the tangent in degrees; non-tabular and very precise, but about half as fast as tanDeg(float). This method is only very slightly more precise than tanDeg(), though the error almost certainly balloons significantly near the undefined inputs at odd multiples of 90. The main reason to use this method is that it is non-tabular. If the SIN_TABLE and COS_TABLE arrays are not in processor cache, this non-tabular method may become faster.
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      degrees - a float angle in degrees, where 0 to 360 is one rotation
      Returns:
      a float approximation of tan()

    • tanTurnsPrecise

      public static float tanTurnsPrecise(float turns)
      Returns the tangent in turns; non-tabular and very precise, but about half as fast as tanTurns(float). This method is only very slightly more precise than tanTurns(), though the error almost certainly balloons significantly near the undefined inputs at odd multiples of 0.25. The main reason to use this method is that it is non-tabular. If the SIN_TABLE and COS_TABLE arrays are not in processor cache, this non-tabular method may become faster.
      Based on Jolt's trigonometry code. Jolt used an original implementation by Stephen L. Moshier. Jolt is MIT-licensed.
      Parameters:
      turns - a float angle in turns, where 0.0 to 1.0 is one rotation
      Returns:
      a float approximation of tan()

    • atan

      public static float atan(float i)
      Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise). This method is usually about 4x faster than Math.atan(double), but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation.
      Parameters:
      i - an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
      Returns:
      an output from the inverse tangent function in radians, from -HALF_PI to HALF_PI inclusive

    • atanDeg

      public static float atanDeg(float i)
      Arc tangent approximation returning a value measured in positive or negative degrees, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
      Parameters:
      i - an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
      Returns:
      an output from the inverse tangent function in degrees, from -90 to 90 inclusive

    • atanTurns

      public static float atanTurns(float i)
      Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
      Parameters:
      i - an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
      Returns:
      an output from the inverse tangent function in turns, from -0.25 to 0.25 inclusive

    • atan

      public static double atan(double i)
      Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise). This method is usually about 4x faster than Math.atan(double), but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation.
      Parameters:
      i - an input to the inverse tangent function; any double is accepted
      Returns:
      an output from the inverse tangent function in radians, from -HALF_PI to HALF_PI inclusive

    • atanDeg

      public static double atanDeg(double i)
      Arc tangent approximation returning a value measured in positive or negative degrees, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
      Parameters:
      i - an input to the inverse tangent function; any double is accepted
      Returns:
      an output from the inverse tangent function in degrees, from -90 to 90 inclusive

    • atanTurns

      public static double atanTurns(double i)
      Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
      Parameters:
      i - an input to the inverse tangent function; any double is accepted
      Returns:
      an output from the inverse tangent function in turns, from -0.25 to 0.25 inclusive

    • atan2

      public static float atan2(float y, float x)
      A fast approximation of Math.atan2(double, double) that is only defined for finite input arguments. The atan2() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in radians from the origin to the given point. If y is non-negative, this returns a float from 0.0 to PI, otherwise it returns a float from -0.0 to -PI.
      This returns NaN when given infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where y == 0f && x == 0f, this returns y (which may be -0.0); this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns Math.PI when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
      Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on Taylor's article with very useful info. Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955) for its atan() approximation over the (0,1] domain.
      Parameters:
      y - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
      x - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
      Returns:
      the angle in radians from the origin to the given point

    • atan2Deg

      public static float atan2Deg(float y, float x)
      A fast approximation of atan2() in degrees that is only defined for finite input arguments. The atan2Deg() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in degrees from the origin to the given point. If y is non-negative, this returns a float from 0.0 to 180.0 , otherwise it returns a float from -0.0 to -180.0 .
      This returns NaN when given infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where y == 0f && x == 0f, this returns y (which may be -0.0); this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns Math.PI (in radians) when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
      Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on Taylor's article with very useful info. Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955) for its atan() approximation over the (0,1] domain.
      Parameters:
      y - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
      x - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
      Returns:
      the angle in degrees from the origin to the given point

    • atan2Deg360

      public static float atan2Deg360(float y, float x)
      A fast approximation of atan2() in non-negative degrees that is only defined for finite input arguments. The atan2Deg360() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in degrees from the origin to the given point. This returns a float from 0.0 to 360.0, counterclockwise when y points up.
      This returns NaN when given infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where y == 0f && x == 0f, this returns 0.0; this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns Math.PI (in radians) when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
      Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on Taylor's article with very useful info. Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955) for its atan() approximation over the (0,1] domain.
      Parameters:
      y - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
      x - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
      Returns:
      the angle in degrees from the origin to the given point, from 0 to 360

    • atan2Turns

      public static float atan2Turns(float y, float x)
      A fast approximation of atan2() in turns that is only defined for finite input arguments. The atan2Turns() function takes y first, then x, and returns the angle in turns from the origin to the given point. This returns a float from 0.0 to 1.0, counterclockwise when y points up.
      This returns NaN when given infinite arguments (or NaN). In the undefined case where y == 0f && x == 0f, this returns 0.0; this differs from Math.atan2(), which returns Math.PI (in radians) when y is 0.0 and x is -0.0.
      Credit to imuli and Nic Taylor; imuli commented on Taylor's article with very useful info. Uses the "Sheet 13" algorithm from "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (1955) for its atan() approximation over the (0,1] domain.
      Parameters:
      y - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (y is first here!)
      x - any finite float; note the unusual argument order (x is second here!)
      Returns:
      the angle in turns from the origin to the given point, from 0.0 to 1.0

    • asin

      public static float asin(float a)
      Returns arcsine in radians; less accurate than Math.asin but may be faster. Average error of 0.000028447 radians (0.0016298931 degrees), largest error of 0.000067592 radians (0.0038727364 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
      Parameters:
      a - asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
      Returns:
      between -HALF_PI and HALF_PI when a is in the defined range

    • asinDeg

      public static float asinDeg(float a)
      Returns arcsine in degrees. This implementation does not return NaN if given an out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
      Parameters:
      a - asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
      Returns:
      between -90 and 90 when a is in the defined range

    • asinTurns

      public static float asinTurns(float a)
      Returns arcsine in turns. This implementation does not return NaN if given an out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN. Note that unlike atan2Turns(float, float), this can return negative turn values.
      Parameters:
      a - asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
      Returns:
      between -0.25 and 0.25 when a is in the defined range

    • acos

      public static float acos(float a)
      Returns arccosine in radians; less accurate than Math.acos but may be faster. Average error of 0.00002845 radians (0.0016300649 degrees), largest error of 0.000067548 radians (0.0038702153 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
      Parameters:
      a - acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
      Returns:
      between 0 and PI when a is in the defined range

    • acosDeg

      public static float acosDeg(float a)
      Returns arccosine in degrees. This implementation does not return NaN if given an out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
      Parameters:
      a - acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
      Returns:
      between 0 and 180 when a is in the defined range

    • acosTurns

      public static float acosTurns(float a)
      Returns arccosine in turns. This implementation does not return NaN if given an out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
      Parameters:
      a - acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
      Returns:
      between 0 and 0.5 when a is in the defined range
